body: This cleans up the file transfer handling in Messenger.c This is not an attempt at fixing the file transfer speed issues as #1668 but rather to make it easier to fix the underlying issue. What I discovered so far: - The API doesn't specify if the `tox_file_send_chunk(...)` function needs to be called from within the `tox_file_chunk_request_cb(...)` callback or not, this makes things a bit complicated and makes it necessary to have an upper bound in that loop: https://github.com/TokTok/c-toxcore/commit/cef05b09c2f2b7b8a3f21d7e1d57c020fb60137e#diff-8037ee1b3b255c1647cf069de86dfb665280b3e80ef565d604c4d9bb221c0108R1563 (@zoff99 I think this answers your question from the comment) - File transfer speed is throttled by two conditions 1) The buffer is filled with a fixed amount of data packets 2) Congestion control is active AFAICT 1) is the main case for throttling of file transfer speed - With the current code, up to 16 file chunks per active transfer are queued, but never more. This could limit file transfer speed even before the other limits are applied. Thus #1668 may work as a workaround for some cases. ping @anthonybilinski --- This change isâ€‚[](https://reviewable.io/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/1674)

comment_data.body: nit: add "." at end of sentence.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1461,52 +1455,47 @@ int file_data(const Messenger *m, int32_t friendnumber, uint32_t filenumber, uin
  * @param userdata The client userdata to pass along to chunk request callbacks.
  * @param free_slots A pointer to the number of free send queue slots in the
  *   crypto connection.
+ * @return true if there's still work to do, false otherwise

comment_regular_data.body:
Tested by building with trace logs and running two clients inside a network namespace with a VPN to half way across the world with about 160ms one way. The effective distance one way between the two profiles is that distance x2, and the round trip is that distance x4. This should hopefully be pretty "real world" network conditions.

Transfers seem to work like before between them - I saw no failures or crashes, did see the sawtooth / shark fin speed ramping up and down, as expected. I thought it was odd that this log wasn't hit: https://github.com/TokTok/c-toxcore/pull/1674/files#diff-8037ee1b3b255c1647cf069de86dfb665280b3e80ef565d604c4d9bb221c0108R1489 since I thought this wave behaviour was due to congestion control, but sudden6 expected that it wouldn't be, and I haven't investigated further.

Code not reviewed yet, and no other testing done.

@zoff99 I'm pretty sure that line was a bug (pls correct me if I'm wrong), because what I think the code was supposed to do was:

1) Calculate the number of slots that can be used for filetransfer
2) If a file transfer is active, request data from the client and decrement free slots
3) Iterate over all running file transfers, until:
    a) Maximum iteration count reached
    b) All slots for file transfer are full
    c) No more data to send

The line you linked, continously subtracts `ft->slots_allocated` from `free_slots`, thus messing up the counting.

yeah i'm not sure what it was supposed to do.
but with your PR ```slots_allocated``` is now useless and never used in any condition anymore.
because that line was the only line where ```slots_allocated``` was checked.

@irungentoo what is ```slots_allocated``` used for? what should it do?

https://github.com/TokTok/c-toxcore/blob/a71ddc7eac5cb62dfa15f30f01d22a0b84f47267/toxcore/Messenger.c#L1441-L1443

https://github.com/TokTok/c-toxcore/blob/a71ddc7eac5cb62dfa15f30f01d22a0b84f47267/toxcore/Messenger.c#L1525

https://github.com/TokTok/c-toxcore/blob/a71ddc7eac5cb62dfa15f30f01d22a0b84f47267/toxcore/Messenger.c#L1500
maybe it can be removed entirely then?

I removed `slots_allocated`, it was introduced in 7e5ca487b5ad1b3482c731d7b26e3e8bfee619f4 to AFAICT keep track of how many slots are allocated to one file transfer and to limit that number. In the current code however, the slots are always distributed in an round robin fashion between the active file transfers and this variable seems like a leftover missed during porting.
